Award.AwardTitle: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH: Phylogenetic and phytochemical cascades in the evolution of tropical diversity
Award.AbstractNarration:
A central goal of modern biology is to understand the origin and maintenance of biodiversity. In particular, understanding the enormous diversity of tropical communities has been a serious challenge. The research group addresses this challenge by using a well-studied tropical system composed of plants, specialist caterpillars feeding exclusively on this group of plants, and a group of specialist wasps that attack the caterpillars. The diversity within each of these groups is enormous (>2,000 species), and the goal for this project is to better understand the evolution of biodiversity by testing specific hypotheses addressing patterns of plant chemical evolution and the role of plant chemistry in biodiversity. To address these hypotheses, the collaborative group consists of two synthetic chemists to elucidate the plant chemistry, one molecular ecologist to reconstruct the evolutionary history of each group, three taxonomists to describe and identify organisms, and two chemical ecologists to describe the interaction between each group.

The hypothesis that the evolution of one organismal group (i.e. plants) can affect the evolution of another interacting group (i.e. caterpillars) is not a new idea; however, the approach to address this hypothesis is novel, as they focus on multiple feeding groups (plants, caterpillars, wasps), which has rarely been undertaken. In addition, the diverse collaborative team allows the team to thoroughly explore all aspects of this system to yield high explanatory power for the question addressed. Finally, understanding the evolution of biodiversity will help with conservation efforts to maintain species rich ecosystems so that the interactions that give structure to ecosystems remain intact.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goals of this project were to understand the evolution of plant chemical defense, and furthermore to understand whether the types of compounds produced had an effect on the evolution of insects that feed on the plants. We hypothesized that plant species that are closely related would have different chemical fingerprints, and that plants with more types of compounds (i.e. greater diversity) would have more types of insects feeding on them.

As we hypothesized, we discovered that the chemical fingerprint in closely related plants were different. However, there were exceptions to this pattern for certain compounds that were found in common between closely related plants. These compounds that were found in common are very interesting in that they may be especially good at protecting the plant from insects. 

We also discovered that plants with many different types of chemical compounds were more likely to have specialized caterpillars feeding on them as well as a greater diversity (or more types) of caterpillars feeding on them. These results are important for understanding how plant chemistry can affect insect feeding preference. They are also important for identifiying plant compounds that may have potential for theraputic activity.

Finally, we found strong evidence for specialization in herbivore dietary preference with decreasing latitude. In other words, herbivores in the tropics are more likely to eat fewer plants than herbivores in temperate ecosystems.

During the course of this funding, we trained over twenty undergraduate students in chemical ecology, seven graduate students, and one postdoctoral scholar. We also trained high school students, K-12 teachers, HSBC bankers, and volunteers from the general public on conducting field work, plant chemical extraction and isolation, and the science of climate change.
